remixlab.proscene
Class Scene

java.lang.Object
  remixlab.proscene.Scene
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener, java.awt.event.MouseWheelListener, java.util.EventListener, javax.swing.event.MouseInputListener, processing.core.PConstants
public class Scene
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.awt.event.MouseWheelListener, javax.swing.event.MouseInputListener, processing.core.PConstants

A processing 3D interactive scene. A Scene provides a default interactivity for your scene through the mouse and keyboard in the hope that it should fit most user needs. For those users whose needs are not completely fulfill by default, proscene main interactivity mechanisms can easily be extended to fit them.

A Scene has a full reach Camera, an two means to manipulate objects: an interactiveFrame() single instance (which by default is null) and a mouseGrabber() pool.

To use a Scene, you can instantiate a Scene object directly or you can implement your own derived Scene class. You also need to call defaultKeyBindings() from your PApplet.keyPressed() function. That's all there is to it.

If you instantiate your own Scene object you should implement your PApplet.draw() as usual, but enclosing your drawing calls between beginDraw() and endDraw(). Thus, for instance, if the following code define the body of your PApplet.draw():

scene.beginDraw();
processing drawing routines...
scene.endDraw();

you would obtain full interactivity to manipulate your scene "for free".

If you derive from Scene instead, you should implement proscenium() which defines the objects in your scene. Then all you have to do is to call draw() from PApplet.draw(), e.g., public void draw() {scene.draw();} (supposing scene is an instance of the Scene derived class).

See the examples BasicUse and AlternativeUse for an illustration of both techniques.

mouseGrabber

public MouseGrabber mouseGrabber()
Returns the current MouseGrabber, or null if none currently grabs mouse events.

When MouseGrabber.grabsMouse(), the different mouse events are sent to it instead of their usual targets (camera() or interactiveFrame()).

defaultKeyBindings

public void defaultKeyBindings()
Associates interactivity actions to default keys.

help

public void help()
Displays the help text describing how interactivity actions are binded to the keyboard and mouse.

init

public void init()
This method is called before the first drawing and should be overloaded to initialize stuff not initialized in PApplet.setup(). The default implementation is empty.

Typical usage include camera() initialization (showAll()) and Scene state setup (setAxisIsDrawn(boolean), setGridIsDrawn(boolean) setHelpIsDrawn(boolean)).

draw

public void draw()
Main paint method.

Calls the following methods, in that order:
beginDraw(): Sets processing camera parameters from the Camera and displays axis and grid accordingly to user flags.
proscenium(): Main drawing method that could be overloaded.
endDraw(): Displays some visual hints, such the help() text.

beginDraw

public void beginDraw()
Sets the processing camera parameters from camera() and displays axis and grid accordingly to user flags

proscenium

public void proscenium()
The method that actually defines the scene.

If you build a class that inherits from Scene, this is the method you should overload, but no if you instantiate your own Scene object (in this case you should just overload PApplet.draw() to define your scene).

The processing camera set in beginDraw() converts from the world to the camera coordinate systems. Vertices given in scene() can then be considered as being given in the world coordinate system. The camera is moved in this world using the mouse. This representation is much more intuitive than a camera-centric system (which for instance is the standard in OpenGL).

endDraw

public void endDraw()
Displays some visual hints, such the help() text.

drawArrow

public static void drawArrow(float length,
                             float radius)
Draws a 3D arrow along the positive Z axis.

length and radius define its geometry.

Use drawArrow(PVector, PVector, float) to place the arrow in 3D.

drawGrid

public static void drawGrid(float size,

size (processing scene units) and nbSubdivisions define its geometry.

mouseMoved

public void mouseMoved(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event)
Implementation of the MouseMotionListener interface method.

Sets the Camera from processing camera parameters.

setMouseGrabber(MouseGrabber) to the MouseGrabber that grabs the mouse (or to null if none of them grab it).

Specified by:
mouseMoved in interface java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener

mousePressed

public void mousePressed(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event)
Implementation of the MouseMotionListener interface method.

When the user clicks on the mouse: If a mouseGrabber() is defined, MouseGrabber.mousePressEvent(MouseEvent, Camera) is called. Otherwise, the camera() or the interactiveFrame() interprets the mouse displacements, depending on mouse bindings.

Specified by:
mousePressed in interface java.awt.event.MouseListener
See Also:
mouseDragged(MouseEvent)

mouseDragged

public void mouseDragged(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event)
Implementation of the MouseMotionListener interface method.

Mouse drag event is sent to the mouseGrabber() (if any) or to the camera() or the interactiveFrame(), depending on mouse bindings.

Specified by:
mouseDragged in interface java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener
See Also:
mouseMoved(MouseEvent)

mouseReleased

public void mouseReleased(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event)
Implementation of the MouseMotionListener interface method.

Calls the mouseGrabber(), camera() or interactiveFrame() mouseReleaseEvent method.

Specified by:
mouseReleased in interface java.awt.event.MouseListener

mouseClicked

public void mouseClicked(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event)
Implementation of the MouseMotionListener interface method.

Implements mouse double click events: left button aligns scene, middle button shows entire scene, and right button centers scene.

Specified by:
mouseClicked in interface java.awt.event.MouseListener
